results.title: 1976 kayak canoe Olympics. No. 13
results.brief_description: Part thirteen of a series which record the last three days of heats, repercharges and semi-finals of the 1976 Olympic Canoe and Kayak races in Montreal, 1976. Excellent for stroke analysis and coaching, as it includes slow motion close-ups of the best paddlers in the world. The 500m and 1000m finals are shown. Photographed by Dr. Stan Plagenhoef.
results.description: Part thirteen of a series which record the last three days of heats, repercharges and semi-finals of the 1976 Olympic Canoe and Kayak races in Montreal, 1976. results.creator_credit: Atlantic Productions, Daniel Grodnik, Bill Badalato and Ernest Thompson
results.brief_description: It was the end of high school and nearing the end of an era when teenage friends Scott (Kiefer Sutherland) and Ralph (Robert Downey Jr) face the full brunt of events in society at the time - the war in Vietnam, Neil Armstrong walking on the moon, and a boom in hippie culture. Scott, a pacifist, has a brother in Vietnam and clashes with his father over his views. Ralph seems to be avoiding the issue through drugs - much to the chagrin of Scott, and Scott’s younger sister, Beth (Winona Ryder), who takes on a bigger role in their lives. In the space of one Summer, two families are drawn together by love, death and war, changing their relationship to one another and society irrevocably. Features a soundtrack of classic 60’s music. Cast also includes Bruce Dern and Mariette Hartley.

results.title: 1945: the year that shaped our world
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation and Therese Denny
results.brief_description: Documentary focusing on Europe and Britain after the end of World War II, showing the social and political changes that were in the air. The events of that years are reconstructed from film shot at the time.

results.title: 1945-1989: the Cold War (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society and Sidney Platt
results.brief_description: Within two years of the end of World War II, the alliance between the United States and the Soviet Union was shattered and for the next 40 years global affairs were dominated by the battle for ideological and material supremacy between the two superpowers: a battle fought through espionage and propaganda. The Cold War resulted in the nuclear arms race and in the “space race”, as well as entrenching either Soviet or US domination throughout the developing world. The video explores the Cold War from the beginning of President Truman’s policy of “containment” in Greece; to the formation of NATO and the Warsaw Pact; through the Korean, Vietnam and Afghanistan wars; through the Cuban Missile Crisis; the revolts against Soviet domination in Hungary and Czechoslovakia; to the destruction of the Berlin Wall which symbolised the end of the Cold War and totalitarian Communism.

results.title: 1945-1989: the Cold War
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society and Sidney Platt
results.brief_description: Within two years of the end of World War two, the alliance between the United States and the Soviet Union was shattered and for the next 40 years global affairs were dominated by the battle for ideological and material supremacy between the two superpowers: a battle fought through espionage and propaganda. The Cold War resulted in the nuclear arms race, “the space race”, as well as entrenching either Soviet or US domination throughout the developing world. The video explores the Cold War from the beginning of President Truman’s policy of “containment” in Greece; to the formation of NATO and the Warsaw Pact; through the Korean, Vietnam and Afghanistan wars; the revolts against Soviet domination in Hungary and Czechoslovakia; the Cuban Missile Crisis; to the destruction of the Berlin Wall in 1989 which symbolised the end of the Cold war and totalitarian communism.

results.title: 1929-1941: The Great Depression
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society and Sidney Platt
results.brief_description: The video offers a history of the Great Depression in the United States. The economic boom of the early 1920’s, built on speculation and deferred borrowings, ended with the stock market crash of 1929. One quarter of American working people became unemployed in a time where government health care and unemployment assistance was non-existent. The video examines the causes of the global depression; the rise of militancy in the U.S. labour movement; the depression on the land; and looks at President Roosevelt’s New Deal and some of the programs his administration initiated to assist the poor. The final end to the depression only came with the rise of Nazism in Europe and the increase in global production geared towards the war effort.
